context.text: The debtor here, Wallace's Bookstores, had had dealings with a number of Virginia State agencies before going into bankruptcy.

context.text: The peculiar nature of bankruptcy jurisdiction, combined with the history of the bankruptcy power, persuades us of the following:  the states agreed in the plan of the convention not to assert sovereign immunity in proceedings like those at issue here, proceeding seeking turnover of preferential transfers.

context.text: We do not rest our decision on any express statement Congress has made on the subject of state sovereign immunity; the relevant abrogation is the one reflected in the plan of the convention, not by statute.

context.text: Congress may at its option either treat states like other creditors insofar as concerns laws on the subject of bankruptcies or exempt them from operation of those laws.

context.text: Military commissions historically have taken three forms: first, they have been used to stand in for civilian courts and to try civilian crimes in territory governed by military law when the civilian courts are closed.

context.text: If... if it was, then it would be perfectly okay, I suppose, to have government subsidies for some parties and not for others, or to have... let some people use public facilities and not others.

League of United Latin American Citizens.speaker: Justice Kennedy
League of United Latin American Citizens.case_name: League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry
League of United Latin American Citizens.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 01, 2006

context.speaker: Nina Perales
context.text: The... the Court held in Bush v. Vera that you cannot use race as a proxy for partisanship.

context.speaker: Nina Perales
context.text: You cannot make that assumption.

context.speaker: Nina Perales
context.text: So if the State--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, but... but that was because it was deliberate in that case, and that's not the hypothetical that Justice Scalia has posed.

context.speaker: Nina Perales
context.text: --In this case, we contend that the State removed Latino voters from district 23 because they were Latino and that--

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: But that's not the hypothetical that was posed to you by the Justice.

League of United Latin American Citizens.speaker: Justice Souter
League of United Latin American Citizens.case_name: League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry
League of United Latin American Citizens.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 01, 2006

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But is it... is it wrong under the Equal Protection Clause or is it wrong under section 2?

context.speaker: Nina Perales
context.text: It's wrong under both, we would argue in our brief.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: No.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: But on Justice... Justice Scalia's hypothesis, there is no intention to remove Latinos as Latinos.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And maybe the answer to that is if you're removing Latinos, it does not matter whether your motivation is invidious or not.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: I don't know whether that's your position.

League of United Latin American Citizens.speaker: Justice Roberts
League of United Latin American Citizens.case_name: League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry
League of United Latin American Citizens.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 01, 2006

context.speaker: Nina Perales
context.text: It doesn't make you a Democrat in that sense that race and partisanship are completely interchangeable so that the State can scoop in and grab 100,000 people of the same race and then say later, well, we were taking out Democrats.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: It's not just the State that's saying it, though.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: You have a district court finding that ethnicity was not the predominant factor, that politics was the predominant factor.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Maybe... as Justice Scalia suggests, maybe they were right, maybe they were wrong, but the point was that it was being done for political purposes not for ethnic purposes.

context.speaker: Nina Perales
context.text: We agree, Mr. Chief Justice, that the end goal was political in the sense of incumbency protection, but a State may not use race as the means to the end of protecting an incumbent.

context.speaker: Nina Perales
context.text: What happened here was that the only group of voters who had shifted their support away from Congressman Bonilla were Latino.

League of United Latin American Citizens.speaker: Justice Breyer
League of United Latin American Citizens.case_name: League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry
League of United Latin American Citizens.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 01, 2006

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: Her claim has focused on... as... as it concerns racial gerrymandering, not that the legislature did too much of it, but... but in a sense that it should have done more.

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: It should have been more aggressive in seeking to create majority minority districts.

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: And... and the district court has factual findings that rule against those claims.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: Would a... I'd like you to elaborate a little because, as I understood your claim, particularly in response to Justice Stevens, you agree that if 23 violated section 2, they can't make up for it somewhere else.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: You agree they can't make up for it particularly when their only way is for political reasons.

context.speaker: Stephen G. Breyer
context.text: But your argument is they never violated... that 23 as redrawn didn't violate section 2.

League of United Latin American Citizens.speaker: Justice Souter
League of United Latin American Citizens.case_name: League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry
League of United Latin American Citizens.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 01, 2006

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Go ahead.

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: I'm sorry.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: --In... in contrast to that, however, you could not make that argument or... or that response with respect to... to district 24, the district in which the... the black vote was... was cracked.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: And in response to earlier questions from Justice Stevens, you... you mentioned there were a number of motivations for dividing it up the way it did, and... and yet, as you also acknowledge, those differing motivations don't answer a... a section 2 argument.

context.speaker: David H. Souter
context.text: What is your answer to the section 2 claim?

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: Well, as you know, Justice Souter, purpose under the '82 amendment is irrelevant to section 2.

League of United Latin American Citizens.speaker: Justice Stevens
League of United Latin American Citizens.case_name: League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry
League of United Latin American Citizens.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 01, 2006

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Supposing we said they have an absolute right to do that with one caveat, that any new district has to be more compact... no more... no less compact than its predecessor, wouldn't that avoid all sorts of problems?

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: That could be a salutary policy goal, and... and Congress could certainly enact that.

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: But I... I see no... no source in the Constitution placing that requirement upon States particularly--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: We have... we have quite a history, as you just identified in your response to Justice Kennedy, of being concerned about particularly grotesque shapes, and that's why they developed these tests of compactness for use in this very litigation.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And the fact that the lawyers have come up with this approach to it makes me think maybe it does have some relevance to the whole problem we're trying to confront.

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: --At an extreme level, lack of compactness can indicate something was going on.

League of United Latin American Citizens.speaker: Justice Kennedy
League of United Latin American Citizens.case_name: League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry
League of United Latin American Citizens.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 01, 2006

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: --But lack of compactness does not... no one has brought a racial gerrymandering claim with respect to districts other than 25 and, to some extent, 23, although the 23 challenge is not a typical racial gerrymandering claim.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: No, but I'm suggesting the challenge to 24 should be a political gerrymandering challenge.

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: I understand that, although a majority of the Court in Vieth concluded that in order for a political gerrymandering claim to succeed, that there must be a substantive standard for fairness to measure the map against some baseline.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Well, Justice Stevens--

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: And that's the standard I'm suggesting.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Right.

League of United Latin American Citizens.speaker: Justice Scalia
League of United Latin American Citizens.case_name: League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry
League of United Latin American Citizens.title: ORAL ARGUMENT - MARCH 01, 2006

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: --But the Court had before it... appellants urged in Vieth compactness, principles of cracking, principles of packing.

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: One of the dissenting Justices advocated that standard, and yet, a majority of the Court... the plurality explicitly rejected it.

context.speaker: R. Ted Cruz
context.text: And Justice Kennedy's concurrence explicitly rejected the standards discussed in the dissents, including a standard looking to compactness.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: I'm not sure that Justice Stevens is suggesting that as a standard.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: He's suggesting it as a disqualifier.

context.speaker: Antonin Scalia
context.text: If it's not as compact, it's no good, but if it is as compact, he's... I... I don't think he's suggesting it's okay.

League of United Latin American Citizens.speaker: Justice Roberts

League of United Latin American Citizens.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 28, 2006

context.speaker: John G. Roberts, Jr.
context.text: Justice Kennedy has the opinion in 05-204, League of United Latin American Citizens versus Perry, and the consolidated cases.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: These are consolidated cases that come to us on appeal on the appellants’ challenge, a Congressional redistricting map that the Texas Legislature enacted in 2003.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: That 2003 legislative plan replaced a 2001 map.

League of United Latin American Citizens.speaker: Justice Kennedy
League of United Latin American Citizens.case_name: League of United Latin American Citizens v. Perry
League of United Latin American Citizens.title: OPINION ANNOUNCEMENT - JUNE 28, 2006

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Neither the Constitution nor Federal Statutes indicate that it is inherently suspect for a legislature to replace a court-ordered plan with one of its own, and the fact of a mid-decade redistricting alone is no sure indication of an unlawful political gerrymandering.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: At the very end of this claim, the appellants contend that the 2003 plan violates the Constitution’s one person/one vote requirement, and this argument, which depends entirely on reasoning that mirrors the attack on the mid-decade redistricting, similarly fails.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The challenge to the statewide redistricting as an unconstitutional gerrymandering therefore is rejected.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: On this aspect of the case, the Chief Justice, joined by Justice Alito, concur in the judgment; Justice Scalia, joined by Justice Thomas, would dismiss these claims as nonjusticiable; Justices Stevens, Souter, Ginsburg and Breyer join the portion of the judgment declining to revisit justiciability.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Justices Souter and Ginsburg join in rejecting the appellant’s one person/one vote claim; and Justice Stevens in a separate opinion, joined by Justice Breyer, would have found a statewide unconstitutional partisan gerrymandering.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So the second claim refers to District 24.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: They argue that because African-American voters control this Dallas district, its elimination unlawfully dilutes their voting rights.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Prior to the 2003 plan, District 24 voters had elected an Anglo Democrat by the name of Martin Frost in every election since 1978.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Even if African-Americans in the old District 24 can state a vote-dilution claim with only 25% of the voting population, they cannot surmount the District Court’s rejection of their questionable evidence about their ability to elect an African-American candidate of their choice.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The Chief Justice and Justice Alito join my opinion on this point; Justice Scalia and Justice Thomas rely on their position, stated in an earlier case of Holder v. Hall, concur in the judgment on the grounds that Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act does not apply to challenges such as these; in a separate opinion joined by Justice Ginsburg, Justice Souter would have held that a minority group comprising less than 50% of a district’s voting population can state a Section 2 vote-dilution claim; Justice Souter also concluded that Congressman Frost’s support in the African-American community showed he was their candidate of choice, and for these reasons he would vacate the judgment of the District Court and remand for further proceedings; Justice Stevens would have found the elimination of District 24 to be an unconstitutional partisan gerrymandering.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: So the judgment of the Court on this issue is that the challenge to the drawing of the lines for the new District 24 is rejected.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The District Court did not appreciate that creating a noncompact district fails to compensate for dismantling a compact-opportunity district.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: Having found the threshold considerations for Section 2 claim satisfied, we look to the totality of the circumstances.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: After doing so, we conclude that the elimination of the opportunity district violates Section 2.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: The Chief Justice, joined by Justice Alito, would have found no Section 2 violation with respect to Section 23; he would have concluded that new District 25 was an effective minority-opportunity district and that, even if it were not, the totality of the circumstances weighed against finding a Section 2 violation; Justices Scalia and Thomas concur in that dissenting position, again for the reasons that they stated in Holder versus Hall.

context.speaker: Anthony M. Kennedy
context.text: In summary, because the 2003 Plan violates Section 2, the Court does not address the claim that use of race in politics in drawing District 23 violates equal protection under the First Amendment Clause.

context.text: Because each of their opinions -- that is, Justice Scalia’s opinion and Justice Kennedy’s opinion -- explains why the other’s is unfaithful to the statute, I shall merely explain why those in dissent agree with the Corps, with the unanimous view of the district and circuit judges who reviewed the evidence in these two cases and with the Solicitor General, who represents the Executive branch of the Government, that the fact that these wetlands are adjacent to tributaries of navigable waters is a sufficient basis for the exercise of federal jurisdiction.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: The Corps has simply applied the plain language of regulations that have been in place for over 30 years that were implicitly approved by Congress when it amended the statute in 1977, that were endorsed by this Court’s unanimous decision in Riverside Bayview case in 1985 and that have been enforced in case after case after case for over three decades.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Thus, the issue presented to us when we granted certiorari did not involve any conflict among the lower courts; it was an issue had been well-settled by all three branches of our Government since at least 1985.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Rather than continuing to defer to the Corps’ longstanding interpretation of the statute that Congress authorized them to administer, they have come up with two separate approaches.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Not only are both approaches wrong, as each of them explains in his criticism of the other’s opinion; but more significantly, their joint conclusion represents an unwise shift in our jurisprudence.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
context.text: Since our unanimous decision in 1984 in Chevron against the National Resources Defense Council -- an opinion, by the way, that I am rather proud of -- we have repeatedly held that if statutory language is ambiguous, we should uphold any reasonable interpretation adopted by the expert agency entrusted by Congress with enforcing the statute.

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens

context.speaker: John Paul Stevens
